Award.AwardTitle: Charting the history of reionization with radio observations of the early universe
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Jacobs is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at Arizona State University. The goal of the research is to detect evidence of the first stars, thought to be born sometime about 500 Million years after the Big Bang. These stars emitted intense radiation which burned away the universe's pervasive atmosphere of Hydrogen. As hydrogen accounts for three quarters of the normal matter in the universe, this last global cosmological process underpins much of what is known about cosmology and galaxy formation. However, observing this time period in ordinary star light challenges the world's premier telescopes due to the extreme distance and faintness of the early stars. The goal of this research program is to detect and characterize radio emission from intergalactic hydrogen before and during its ionization using two recently completed radio telescopes. Detecting and characterizing the predicted radio signature of this "Cosmic Dawn" was rated as a top priority by the astronomical community. This project will also support a student volunteer corps who will take a portable a planetarium to schools and who will be directly involved in developing elements for museum and planetarium facilities. These include a state of the art 3D planetarium theater, in the recently constructed Arizona State University astronomy building.

Recent advances in digital technology allow the construction of very large arrays of antennae which provide the necessary sensitivity to detect radio emission from Hydrogen when the universe was only 300Mya old. Emitted at a wavelength of 21cm, the radiation is stretched by cosmological expansion to an observed wavelength of 1.5 to 3m depending on the time period under observation. Both the Murchison Widefield Array (MWA) and the Precision Array for Probing the Epoch of Reionization (PAPER) have been designed to observe these wavelengths at the necessary sensitivity and are constructed, in large part with funding from the National Science Foundation, far from interfering human radio emission; the MWA is in Western Australia and PAPER is in the Karoo desert of South Africa. Using both telescopes, Dr. Jacobs will compile a deep statistical measure of the amount of radiation coming from Hydrogen in the early universe. Portions of the work include performing observations, measuring and removing other bright interfering signals from other bright astronomical objects, and applying this new knowledge to building larger telescopes capable of directly imaging the early universe. These measurements of bright interfering signals will form a substantial, interesting, and compellingly beautiful image of the universe and provide a foundation data set for exhibits produced by the student corps created as a part of the project. The team of undergraduate students will have two goals: First to improve retention of astronomy and science education undergraduates and second to bring planetarium shows to traditionally underserved schools and tribal centers which cannot take advantage of other, more costly, programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to place deep constraints on the emergence of the first stars and galaxies using the radio emission of cosmological hydrogen.  This observable has been proposed as one of the only ways to observe the distribution of matter and energy on large scales in the early universe. This emission is highly redshifted, its wavelength stretched, by cosmological expansion until it is observed at between 1 and 4 meters depending on its distance.  The signal is faint and observed against a much brighter foreground of galaxies in the nearby universe, an instrument with large collecting area and precision greater than 1 part in 10^5 is required.   Such arrays are currently being developed by several groups around the globe.  This project focused on the development of instrumentation and analysis techniques necessary to detect and analyze the 21cm signal. Instruments under study include the Murchison Widefield Array (MWA) in Western Australia, the Precision Array for Probing the Epoch of Reionization (PAPER) in South Africa and the Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array (HERA) also in South Africa.  


The goal of these projects is to make a statistical detection of 21cm power and use this power spectrum to eliminate models of early evolution.  Several significant outcomes from this project have been studies of newly developed statistical analysis pipelines as applied to real data, and comparing against simulation.  The result has been a step in maturity of analysis across the community to a higher standard of result. Changes include an emphasis on comparison multiple reduction and a more common use of instrument simulation.  A second outcome has been the invention of a new type of calibration instrument.  One problem which emerged from several points was the importance of absolute calibration of direction dependent gains.  The fellowship created the opportunity to develop the External Calibrator for Hydrogen Observatories (ECHO), a drone mounted calibration source which maps out the direction dependent response of fixed radio arrays like MWA, PAPER and HERA.  ECHO development has been supported by the NSF Advanced Technologies and Instrumentation program. Early tests have been achieved levels similar to other methods and development of a more advanced system capable of delivering sensitivity necessary for HERA is now under way.


The broader impact of the fellowship was in the inclusion students at ASU in both outreach and research and on the students, teachers and families at underserved schools who participated in outreach events. The School for Earth and Space Exploration runs a program where teachers in area schools can check out a portable planetarium for use in their schools. However many schools do not have the resources to send teachers to the required training.  To spread the impact of this fellowship, ASU students were recruited to take the planetarium to those schools and area tribal centers. Hundreds of children often with their families were able to see the night sky, sometimes for the first time. The ASU students were drawn from a diverse group including women, minorities, and first generation college attendees. Many of these students went on from the outreach roles to participate in the ECHO project which was staffed entirely by undergraduates.  Several of these students have moved on to graduate school in astronomy and positions in industry.
